Award.AwardTitle: SCH: Student Travel Support for IEEE Conference on Connected Health (CHASE 2018)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is to support student travel and participation in the IEEE Conference on Connected Health (CHASE 2018) in Arlington, VA. CHASE provides a supportive scientific forum for students focusing on computing and engineering research associated with the multidisciplinary field of connected health. CHASE provides a forum for expert and peer critique of students' research with the goal of improving their science. Student participants will also have the opportunity to receive networking support and career advice from internationally-recognized experts. Overall, the travel support brings together people who might not otherwise engage with one another and engage in multidisciplinary research in fields involving connected health.

This proposal supports doctoral students by providing a Student Research Forum focused on encouraging students to examine technologies from multiple perspectives to understand how innovative technology, usable systems, and sound medical information combine to make the most impact. In addition, the Career Panel enables students to see different career paths for researchers in this area. The CHASE conference exposes participants to different scientific disciplinary approaches, supports networking with conference attendees and is designed to support the development of the next generation of scholars in connected health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Third IEEE/ACM Conference on Connected Health: Applications, Systems and Engineering Technologies (IEEE/ACM CHASE 2018) awarded twenty-two applicants from 19 different US-based institutions for NSF student travel awards after a well-designed committee-based review process. These award recipients include graduate (Ph.D/Master) and undergraduate students. They all have excellent academic records and have been conducting research in the smart and connected health area in US-based institutions. These award recipients presented their work in the format of full conference papers, poster and demo papers, or workshop papers at the IEEE/ACM CHASE 2018 conference. Five out of twenty-two award recipients are female students.   

Participation in IEEE/ACM CHASE contributes an important part to students' research and career development in connected health. It offers a great opportunity for students to not only present their own work at this conference, attend panel and keynote sessions, and participate in technical sessions, but also to interact with their peers and senior researchers. The experience at IEEE/ACM CHASE could enable students to understand more cutting-edge work in the fields of smart and connected health systems. This NSF student travel award promotes more participation of the US-based graduate students who would otherwise be unable to attend IEEE/ACM CHASE. The project helps educate the next generation scientists andengineers in the field of smart and connected health.


Last Modified: 05/01/2019
Modified by: Hua Fang
